none: Translated title: Fāʼidah to cure every illness
Part of the Maktaba grant project (Local Note)
In Arabic in Maghrebi style script (Language Note)
Arabic Manuscripts from West Africa--The ‘Umar Falke Collection

A fāʾida (a genre of text offering specific recipes, practices, or actions that promise the user assistance in times of need) from northern Nigeria dating from the late nineteenth or early twentieth centuries. The purpose of this fāʾida is to cure every illness, with the exception of death. The remedy involves boiling plants and writing verses from the "Burda" of al-Būṣīrī (d. 1294).

The images on this web site are from material in the collections of the Melville J. Herskovits Library of African Studies at Northwestern University Libraries, are provided for use by its students, faculty and staff, and by other researchers visiting this site, for research consultation and scholarly purposes only. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of the images from this site is not permitted.
Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections API
Homepage at Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections

This rare collection of manuscripts dates back to the 19th and 20th centuries and come from mainly northern Nigeria (Kano in particular) but also includes items from Ghana, Senegal and Mali. Mostly handwritten in Arabic and Ajami scripts, these manuscripts cover a wide range of subjects from Arabic grammar, history, theology, law and astronomy to name a few, with particular strength in Tijâniyya Sufi order and Hausa poetry.   Comprised of 5,000 items, the manuscripts are split across four separate collections and serve as an excellent example of West African literacy in Arabic:  The 'Umar Falke Collection, The John Paden Collection, The John Hunwick Collection, The University of Ghana Collection

body.value:
*Translated by Paul Naylor* 



In the name of God, the Most Gracious the Most Merciful. May God's blessings be upon the Holy Prophet.

*Fāʾida* to cure every illness of a son of Adam whether it be in his head, his bones, stomach, ears, or leprosy, with the exception of death. And it requires these plants, with the blessing of God Almighty, and boil them: the first of them *turaga,*[^1] then *sanya,*[^2] *jnkfa*,[^3] *samsami, farar kaya,*[^4] *tumfafiya,*[^5] *magarya*,[^6] gauɗe,[^7] *ghndu*[^8], yandiya[^9], *tsamiya* and *sandam mayu*,[^10] as well as these verses \[from the *Burda*\]:

- He is the beloved of God whose intercession is hoped for

  - In the face of every dread and unexpected horror.[^11]

- But he whom God protects has no need

  - For double-knit chain-mail nor lofty strongholds[^12]

- O best of those whose courtyard the supplicants seek, hastening on foot

  - Or on the backs of she-camels whose heavy tread leaves traces on the ground[^13]

- How many an invalid was cured by the touch of his hand?

  - How many a madman was released from his affliction?[^14]

- Whoever is succored by the Messenger of God, if lions

  - Were to find him in their lair, they would fall silent.[^15]

- It is miracle enough for you that an illiterate should achieve such knowledge

  - In the Age of Ignorance, that an orphan should acquire such refinement[^16]

- O Messenger of God, it will not offend your dignity to help me

  - When God, the Generous One, is endowed with the name of the Avenger.[^17]

- That never did I suffer injustice and seek his protection

  - But that he extended his protection over me and I met no harm[^18]

- Praise be to God in public and in private

  - and thanks be to God at the beginning and at the conclusion[^19]

Finished. 

[^1]: Possibly *turaga zumu*, which Blench identifies as a type of asparagus. This and some of the other pharmacological references are taken from Roger Blench, ""Hausa Names for Plants and Trees"" (2nd ed.), online publication, 2007, <http://www.rogerblench.info/Ethnoscience/Plants/General/Hausa%20plant%20names.pdf>.

[^2]: *Securidaca longepedunculata*, known as violet tree.

[^3]: Unidentified.

[^4]: *Acacia sieberana*, known as paperbark thorn.

[^5]: Giant milkweed.

[^6]: Jujube tree.

[^7]: A thorny shrub from the bush.

[^8]: Unidentified.

[^9]: *Leptadenia hastata*, used as a condiment in soups.

[^10]: Possibly *sandan maya*, for which Blench lists three different trees.

[^11]: *Qasīdat al-Burda* (Ode of the Mantle), verse 36. This ode of praise for the Prophet Muḥammad (henceforth ""*Burda*,"" was composed by Imam al-Būṣīrī (d.1294, Egypt). This and subsequent translations of the *Burda* are taken from Suzanne Stetkevych, *The Mantle Odes: Arabic Praise Poems to the Prophet Muhammad* (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 2010).

[^12]: *Burda*, verse 79.

[^13]: *Burda*, verse 105.

[^14]: *Burda*, verse 85.

[^15]: *Burda*, verse 135.

[^16]: *Burda*, verse 139.

[^17]: *Burda*, verse 153.

[^18]: *Burda*, verse 80.

[^19]: While resembling the *Burda* in style and in rhyming letter (mīm), I could not find this passage in published editions of the text. Arabic: الحمد لله في سري وفي علني وشكر لله في بدو ومختتم"

"بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم صلى الله على النبي الكريم 

فائد دواء كل مرض من رجل ابن آدم إلى 

رأسه أو كانت في عظمه أو في بطنه أو في 

العزن أو كانت الجزام إلا مرض الموت 

فقط وتطلب هذه الأشجار على بركه الله 

تعالى وأولهم توارغا وسنيا وجنكفا 

وسمسمي وفررفيا وتنفافيا ومعزيا 

وفوطي وغندو وياطيا وطاميا 

وسَنْدَ مَّايُو هكذا ثم هذه الأبيات 

هو الحبيب الذي ترجى شفاعته لكل هول من الأ 

هوال مقتحم⁖ وقاية الله أغنت عن مضاعفة 

من الدروعِ وعن عال من الأطم يا خير من 

يمم العافون ساحته سعيا وفوق متون 

الأينق الرسم كم أبرأت وصبا باللمس 

راحته وأَطلقت أربا من ربقة اللمم و 

من تكن برسول الله نصرته إن تلقه 

الأسد في آجامها تجم كفاك بالعلم 

في الأمي معجزة في الجاهلية وتأديب 

في اليتم ولن يضيق رسول الله جاهك 

بي إذا الكريم تجلى باسم منتقم ما سامني 

الدهر ضيما واستجرت به إلا ونلت جوارا 

منه لم يضم الحمد لله في سر وفي علن وشكر لله 

في بدء ومختتم انتهى. "
"And write it seven times each day for seven \[consecutive\] days, washing with it every day. And success is with God."

"واكتبها سبعة سبعة 

إلى سبعة أيام غاسلا به كل يوم 

وبالله التوفيق "

seo.title: Fāʾida to Cure Every Illness - Maktaba
seo.description: A fāʾida (a genre of text offering specific recipes, practices, or actions that promise the user assistance in times of need) from northern Nigeria dating from the late nineteenth or early twentieth centuries. The purpose of this fāʾida is to cure every illness, with the exception of death. The remedy involves boiling plants and writing verses from the "Burda" of al-Būṣīrī (d. 1294).
